title: UPDATE 3-Oil falls due to caution over first phase of U.S.-China trade deal
text:
© Reuters. UPDATE 3-Oil falls due to caution over first phase of U.S.-China trade deal

* Traders eye U.S.-China pact, await details

* Saudi Arabia reaffirms commitment to OPEC+ supply cuts

* China's oil imports firm in September

(Updates prices, adds Saudi and Russian remarks, analyst comments, changes dateline from SINGAPORE)

By Bozorgmehr Sharafedin

LONDON, Oct 14 (Reuters) - Oil prices fell on Monday as scant details about the first phase of a trade deal between the United States and China undercut optimism over a U.S.-Sino thaw that had helped lift crude markets by 2% at the end of last week.

Brent crude fell 46 cents to $60.05 a barrel by 0840 GMT, while U.S. West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude lost 40 cents at $54.30 a barrel. Both were down 0.7%.

Late on Friday, the United States and China outlined the first stage of a trade deal and suspended this week's scheduled U.S. tariff hikes. But existing tariffs remain in place and officials on both sides said much more work was needed before an accord could be agreed. oil market is taking a cautious stance as to what comes next given that the thorny issues of industrial policy, intellectual property rights, technology transfer among others were not addressed," BNP Paribas (PA: ) oil strategist Harry Tchilinguirian said.

Brent and WTI rose more than 3% last week, their first weekly increase in three.

A good portion of their gains came after the United States announced on Friday it was deploying more troops to Saudi Arabia, and after an Iranian oil tanker was attacked in the Red Sea. the market waits for potential responses from the Iranians, the continued inability of geopolitics to sustain price gains is a testament to the state of concerns over demand," JBC analysts said in a note.

There are also worries that further escalation along the Syrian and Turkish border could affect output or exports from Iraq, providing more support for oil prices. Syrian troops entered a northeastern town on Monday. Saudi energy minister, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, said oil exporters taking part in a global output deal between OPEC and its allies, a grouping known as OPEC+, were showing serious commitment to the cuts. Energy Minister Alexander Novak said there were no talks underway to change the OPEC+ deal.

The compliance of OPEC+ producers with the supply-reduction agreement was seen at above 200% in September, sources familiar with the matter said on Monday. showed strong demand for oil, with its September imports rising 10.8% from a year earlier as refiners ramped up output amid stable profit margins and solid demand for fuel. reporting by Florence Tan and Seng Li Peng; Editing by Dale Hudson)
description: UPDATE 3-Oil falls due to caution over first phase of U.S.-China trade deal
